description.plain:
De La Soul is the Long Island, New York trio consisting of Posdnous, Trugoy the Dove and Maseo. They began as ushers of the “D.A.I.S.Y. Age,” which helped earn them a label of “hip-hop hippies” when they dropped their 1989 debut album, 3 Feet High and Rising.

Along with A Tribe Called Quest and Jungle Brothers, De La Soul were founding members of the Native Tongues collective, a crew that released lighthearted and witty tracks, including De La Soul singles such as “Me, Myself and I,” “Potholes in My Lawn,” “Ring Ring Ring (Ha Ha Hey),” “A Roller Skating Jam Named "Saturdays”," “Breakadawn,” and “Stakes is High” among others.

Their first four albums (3 Feet High and Rising, De La Soul is Dead, Buhloone Mindstate, and Stakes is High) were all critically acclaimed and have each been included on “best of” lists. Their 2016 album, and the Anonymous Nobody, generated buzz as the group raised money on the crowdfunding site Kickstarter to produce the album. They are also known for their multiple collaborations with the animated group Gorillaz, most notably on the single “Feel Good Inc.”

After a long legal battle, it was announced on January 3, 2023 that De La Soul’s first six albums on Tommy Boy would finally be available on streaming platforms on March 1st. On February 5, 2023, Posdnous represented the group at the Grammy Awards as he performed his verse from “Buddy” during a medley performance celebrating the 50th anniversary of hip-hop. One week later, tragedy struck the group as Dave “Trugoy the Dove” Jolicoeur passed away on February 12th at the age of 54. Pos and Maseo celebrated Dave’s life and the release of their music to streaming services at Webster Hall in New York City on March 2nd with “The D.A.I.S.Y. Experience.”

songs.full_title: Me Myself and I by De La Soul
songs.title: Me Myself and I

description.plain:
Released in 1989, De La Soul’s third single “Me Myself and I” established the group’s characteristic style of combining hip hop with humor and social commentary. The group’s frustration concerning their forced-upon hippie label is addressed in the typically dry humor which became the De La Soul trademark. The track contains samples of “(Not Just) Knee Deep” by Funkadelic, “Rapper Dapper Snapper” by Edwin Birdsong, and “Funky Worm” by the Ohio Players.

In the summer of 1989, it became the group’s first (and only) number one on the U.S. R&B chart and first (and only) top 40 on the Hot 100 (aside from their later collaboration with Gorillaz on “Feel Good Inc”). It also reached the top 30 in the UK and was later ranked #46 on VH1’s 100 Greatest Songs of Hip Hop.

It’s also worth noting that its music video – in which the trio are bullied for their “forced-upon” image of hippies while attending a high school class on how to be a mainstream rapper – features doppelgängers of many famous MC’s of the time, each with their own respective styles that De La Soul is not trying to copy for themselves. Lighthearted fun is had at the expense of the likes of Eric B. & Rakim, Run-D.M.C., Kool G. Rap, Doug E. Fresh and others. As the lyrics attest, they are proud of who they are as individuals.

songs.full_title: Stakes Is High by De La Soul
songs.title: Stakes Is High

description.plain: The climactic point of De La Soul’s “Stakes is High” album serves as a criticism to the state of the world in 1996, along with a declaration that the Native Tongues are back in effect. A very sobering, serious track that differs vastly from the playful music that De La Soul has always been known for.

songs.full_title: The Magic Number by De La Soul
songs.title: The Magic Number

description.plain: The song is built on the drum beat from Double Dee and Steinski’s “Lesson 3” – which itself is a sample of Led Zeppelin’s “The Crunge,” making Pos’s claim of “no rock and roll” deeply and probably unintentionally ironic – and heavily samples/interpolates Bob Dorough’s “Three is a Magic Number” from ABC’s “Schoolhouse Rock.”

songs.full_title: Rock Co.Kane Flow by De La Soul (Ft. MF DOOM)
songs.title: Rock Co.Kane Flow

description.plain:
On The Grind Date’s closing track, Posdnous, Dave and MF DOOM each spit their own raw and uncut dope rhymes back to back to back. The first live TV performance of the track occurred on Last Call with Carson Daly on December 4, 2004.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D99Rl606zY4

Jake One provides the hard-hitting track, which flipped a sample from the intro of the 1977 song “Deliverance” by the electronic French group Space. In 2020, Jake conducted an interview with David Ma for Passion of the Weiss where he talked about how he was still working a day job when the beat was selected from a beat CD he gave De La Soul after one of their shows in Jake’s hometown of Seattle. He also talked about how the breakdowns were done by hand on analog equipment as he drew inspiration from the productions of Kanye West and Just Blaze on Roc-A-Fella Records releases such as JAY-Z’s The Dynasty: Roc La Familia and The Blueprint albums.

songs.full_title: Eye Know by De La Soul (Ft. Otis Redding)
songs.title: Eye Know

description.plain:
“Eye Know” is the fifth single from De La Soul’s 3 Feet High and Rising. It was not released as a single in the US, but made the top 30 in several countries overseas, including a #14 peak in the UK.

Its B-side is the non-album track “The Mack Daddy on the Left.”

BBC One used an instrumental version of “Eye Know” for the Saturday’s goals portion of “Match of the Day 2” from 2004 to the end of the 2007/2008 season.

Samples:

Steely Dan’s “Peg” is heavily sampled throughout the song, providing the backing beat and some backup vocals for the chorus.

The Mad Lads' “Make This Young Lady Mine” provides the sample for both the guitar and the horn heard throughout the track.

The whistling heard throughout the track is an Otis Redding sample from his song “(Sittin' On) the Dock of the Bay”

And drums from “Sing a Simple Song” by Sly & the Family Stone are also sampled in the track.

songs.artist_names: De La Soul (Ft. Jungle Brothers & Q-Tip)
songs.full_title: Buddy by De La Soul (Ft. Jungle Brothers & Q-Tip)
songs.title: Buddy

description.plain:
“Buddy” is the fourth single off of De La Soul’s debut album 3 Feet High and Rising, reaching #2 on the US Rap Chart in early 1990. The song features the Jungle Brothers and Q-Tip, both fellow members of the Native Tongues collective.

According to Pitchfork, “Buddy” wasn’t a ‘pal’ or ‘friend’:

Their album would be full of inside jokes [and] invented slang (“A phrase called talk” was their rhyme style, “Public Speaker” was a dope emcee, “Buddy” was a hot body, and “Strictly Dan Stuckie” meant “awesome”).

songs.full_title: Ring Ring Ring (Ha Ha Hey) by De La Soul
songs.title: Ring Ring Ring (Ha Ha Hey)

description.plain:
“Ring Ring Ring” was the lead single of De La Soul’s sophomore album De La Soul Is Dead. It was an international smash hit in the spring of 1991. In the US, it did not appear on the Pop Chart but did peak at #3 on the Rap Chart.

The main groove here is based around a killer combo of The Whatnauts' butter-smooth “Help Is On The Way,” with some Honeydrippers' “Impeach The President” drums and a bass grab via Lou Reed. Its chorus borrows lyrics from “Name And Number” by Curiosity Killed The Cat.

Don’t be mislead by its catchy vibe. Just like OutKast’s “Hey Ya”, it appears like an innocent radio jam, but the lyrics are about not wanting to listen to rappers who want their demo tapes listened to.

songs.full_title: Pain by De La Soul (Ft. Snoop Dogg)
songs.title: Pain

description.plain:
After sharing by surprise a four-track EP For Your Pain and Suffering in April, De La Soul deliver the first single off their upcoming album And the Anonymous Nobody, featuring the legendary and fellow hip-hop OG Snoop Dogg, who gets somewhat introspective during his verse:

Used to gang bang, used to love the clashes / Now cash is the only motivation, but not for me G / I’m into public relations…

Built around a simple guitar-driven funk groove, “Pain” is a meditation on the nature of suffering and what it means to feel pain. It’s a soulful, compassionate track, ultimately. And it comes with an interactive lyric video game that you can play over on De La Soul’s website.

songs.artist_names: De La Soul (Ft. Q-Tip & Vinia Mojica)
songs.full_title: A Roller Skating Jam Named "Saturdays" by De La Soul (Ft. Q-Tip & Vinia Mojica)
songs.title: A Roller Skating Jam Named “Saturdays”
songs.title_with_featured: A Roller Skating Jam Named "Saturdays" (Ft. Q-Tip & Vinia Mojica)

description.plain:
“A Roller Skating Jam Named "Saturdays” is the second single from De La Soul’s second album De La Soul Is Dead. They bring in Vinia Mojica to provide vocals for the chorus and they once again team up with their Native Tongue brother Q-Tip after collaborating with him on both the album version and remix version of “Buddy.”

This bouncy roller rink anthem layers a number of samples with the main beat coming from “Evil Vibrations” by the Mighty Ryeders. The song was later remixed for the single release and featured Q-Tip and Phife Dawg from A Tribe Called Quest along with Dres from Black Sheep.

Posdnuos said he made the “Saturdays” beat for a Native Tongues subgroup called the Fabulous Fleas, which included himself, Q-Tip, Afrika Baby Bam and Juju from The Beatnuts. However, he made it a De La song when their label needed a single, and the Fabulous Fleas never materialized.

songs.full_title: Ego Trippin' (Part Two) by De La Soul
songs.title: Ego Trippin’ (Part Two)

description.plain:
De La’s “Ego Trippin' (Part Two)” is a continuation of the original “Ego Trippin'” by the Ultramagnetic MC’s.

Note that the entire song is a parody of braggadocio Hip Hop with rappers speaking about themselves in superlatives like they’re the greatest thing since sliced bread. It’s done in an almost sarcastic tone.

Part of the song was taken as a dis to Tupac; in the video, it appears that De La Soul is mimicking Tupac in his video for “I Get Around”, and this was also expressed by Tupac’s sister.

A couple of years later after his death, running into his sister, his sister was like, “My brother loved you all very much. He just couldn’t understand why you all did that video ‘Ego Tripping’. It looked like you all was taking shots at him from the ‘I Get Around’ shit.”

songs.full_title: Drawn by De La Soul (Ft. Little Dragon)
songs.title: Drawn

description.plain:
From Update #49 sent to Kickstarter backers;

Yukimi Nagano from Little Dragon describes “Drawn” as “a dreamy journey about not taking anything for granted in life. About love and being lost in something dangerously good.” She added, “we met De La on the Gorillaz tour in 2011. I guess there is a mutual creative respect. We’ve kept in touch since then, naturally, collaborating was bound to happen.”

songs.full_title: Millie Pulled a Pistol on Santa by De La Soul
songs.title: Millie Pulled a Pistol on Santa
songs.title_with_featured: Millie Pulled a Pistol on Santa

description.plain:
Track 15 on 1991’s De La Soul is Dead. Also released as a double A-side single with “Keepin' the Faith.”

One of the group’s bleakest tracks, this song tells the story of a sexually abused girl who can’t get anyone to believe her because her father is a respected member of the community. Eventually, she snaps and kills her father, who is working as a department store Santa Claus.

Minnesota Hip-Hop duo, Atmosphere, made a sequel to the song in 2009, titled Millie Fell Off The Fire Escape
